ravi_1_intro: ^Hey there. I’m Ravi. I’m 24. Aviation engineer.
^Well, ASPIRING aviation engineer, anyway. I’m still in uni.
^One more year to go until I join the working world! I want to be able to support my family soon.
^Family has been just Amma (mother), Revati and I for a while.
^As for Appa... Appa (father) is no longer family.
^He used to be in the airline industry. He’s part of the reason I wanted to become an aviation engineer in the first place.
^He used to sneak Revati and I into the hangars on the weekends, just to look at those airplanes he’d be working on.
^Just looking at those planes, and imagining them take off to the skies – it filled my heart with a great sense of wonder.
^And then...one day, it happened.  It was just another regular day.
^Appa left early in the morning... and didn't come back.
^He left us that day. He’s been uncontactable since. We called and called, but he never picked up.
^Sometimes... I think he wanted to be like the airplanes he worked on, free to roam the skies, to go anywhere they pleased. But I might never find out.
^Since then, Amma, Revati and I have had to fend for ourselves.
^It’s not been easy, especially for Amma. She works a 12-hour shift as a sales assistant at the department store.
^Revati is doing her A levels, and she’s done part-time jobs too.
^My dream is to make life easier for them. If I can fulfill mine, I would be helping theirs too.
^But first, I have grades to keep up, an internship to find, and then hopefully, a job! Like a good Indian boy haha.
^And this is what it’s like, to be me.
ravi_1_1_narration: ^After a tiring day at school, I come home to our little apartment in Tampines.
ravi_1_1: ^Yup, I had dinner. I ate with my classmates after class.
^Ok. But you should know, you missed a great fish curry. Looks like I’ll have to throw the rest away-
^Oh! Maybe I am a little bit hungry after all. Can I have some curry please?
^Aha! I knew it. I don’t think you’ve ever said no to my fish curry.
^Mmmm... Amma's fish curry... Amma doesn't really talk about her feelings, so she expresses her emotions through her cooking, especially her curries.
^Even the neighbours came for it, sold on the bright heat of masala and turmeric that’d waft through the window grilles (not all our neighbours enjoyed the smell though.)

^The dish spoke celebration, until the day Appa disappeared. That day, we sat around crying as Amma heaped thick curry onto our plates – knowing it was the only comfort we could have, a piece of the past we could bring to life through Amma’s cooking skills.
^She conveyed her love, and sometimes sadness, through it.
^Anyway, go shower, you look so sweaty. Then you can eat. I’ll reheat the curry for you.

s: ^It's ok ma, let's eat while it's hot!

c-0: ^A few minutes later, after the fastest cold shower ever...
g-0: ^As always, it smells amazing! I feel like I could eat 10 bowls all by myself. Did you do anything different this time?
^Ah, so you found my secret ingredient! I put in some garam masala (a spice) that Pushpa Aunty gave to us when we went over last week. Very fragrant!
^I think she made it herself. You know how she is.
^Oh nice. Last time we visited her, the sambal she made… also power! She could probably run a sambal chain restaurant! I must have dreamt of her sambal so many times…
^Ravi, before you start... we need to talk about something.

^Yeah. The manager told me this morning.

^Well, it didn’t matter. They asked me to hand in my card anyway.

^What the hell! If the shopping centre is not doing well, they should fire the CEO! Or the manager! Why fire Amma? She’s been so loyal and hardworking. Fire those idiots on top who are responsible.
^It’s not her fault…  Stupid rich businessmen - all they care about is profit and not people! I can see the tears, welling in her eyes. It’s so unfair.

c-6: ^What do you want me to do? I can’t go back there and beg for my job back.
^It’s just… like I said, I’ve worked there for so long. It’s all I know.
c-7: ^Yeah, I did. She is in her room.
^Ever since she was in primary school, I’ve been a sales assistant. I really thought I’d be able to work there until Revati finishes uni.

g-3: ^I thought that I could stay there, and that everything would be fine.
^But it’s ok. What’s done is done. We will have to move on. And also, more importantly, we will have to move out of here.
^I didn’t tell you or Revati about this, but...kanna (dear), we are already two months late for rent.
^We’ve been barely paying it off before then. I don’t earn a lot of money, and I don’t have much savings to spare. I barely have enough to pay it off.
^This place was too big anyway. And I didn’t want to affect Revati. You know she’s studying hard for her A-Levels.
^And for your uni fees next year...I don’t want to touch that money. I can’t afford to.
^Two months late? Why didn’t you tell me or Revati? We could have helped. Even now she isn't telling us how much the rent is.
^If we knew what she'd been dealing with, we could have worked part-time more, we could have made the move sooner…
^And my uni money? I’m not studying just for myself. I need to earn and save for this family. I thought.. my going to uni was good for the family
^Are my uni fees are the reason we’re about to be forced out of a home? I’m not a kid anymore. I have the right to know about our finances so I can help.
^We'll figure this out together. Let me help.

^She can’t help it, and you can’t blame her for it. You know she didn’t mean anything bad.
^It’s time to be the man of the house. You have to step up, Ravi.
^Don’t worry about me. We can figure something out. Maybe we don’t have to move.
^I don’t have a choice! My job is to worry about you.
^And I don’t think we can afford to stay. The landlord has already been very accommodating.
^He’s already waited 2 months for his rent. I don’t think he’ll be willing to wait for one more. We must move out.
^It’s so near to the park, and the neighbours are so friendly...we’ve lived here for so long, Amma.
^Ravi, we have no choice. We have to move on.
c-9: ^  I need to let Amma know she cannot keep such things a secret.
^Because of her need to ‘protect’ us, we’ve ended up in such a bad state. But it’s my fault too... For just coasting along in my ignorance and not bothering to ask.
^Oh. We’re two months late? Why didn’t you tell us?
^You know I can’t. I wanted you and Revati to focus on your studies. I couldn’t have you all worrying about me, or finding another job.
^And it’s not like we’re completely broke! I still have enough saved for your uni fees-
^Amma, you don’t have to do it all on your own, you know. Me and Revati are old enough to help. In fact, I should already be helping out. I’ve been such a blissful idiot.
^Ravi, don’t worry about the money. It’s not your responsibility. It’s mine, and it’s solved.
^Come on, Amma. I’m not a kid anymore. At least please let me find a way to chip in so we don’t lose our home. I feel so useless just standing by.
^...Ravi, it’s not your fault. I want you and Revati to have a bright future. Brighter than mine.
^Which means you have to focus on your uni. Once you’re out and you land a good job, of course it’d be my time to relax.
^Right now, we have no choice. We have to move.

g-4: ^Ok... I get it. Where are we moving to? How much will it cost?
^I have some good news. It won’t cost anything.
^We’re moving to Pushpa aunty’s house. She has a spare room, now that Kamala has moved out with her husband.
^She also needs help around the house. When I called her to ask for help, she was so excited to let us stay with her.
^I think it will be nice to give her some company and help her out
^And when she was growing up in Chennai (in India), it was normal for relatives to stay with each other. So she's happy to have us.
^... but we're not from India Amma - we're from Singapore!
^Kanna, we are still Indian, and families stick together where we are from. On the bright side, you can have all the power sambal you like. I’m sure she won’t mind cooking for everyone again.
^I like Pushpa Aunty and Amma and Revati love talking to her. It’s good that it’ll save us some money.
^...but I know I can’t study there - three of us in that small house - it’s going to be very noisy!
^I can’t afford any bad grades if I’m getting my family a better life. And hell, a better life is what I’m trying to achieve for us.

ravi_2_4_call: ^Should I call her? Maybe I should!
^But what if she doesn't actually like me?  I don’t want to risk losing her as a friend.
^If I don't call her, I wouldn’t need to bring her over to Pushpa Aunty’s place to meet my family. And I wouldn’t need to meet hers.
^That way, I won’t risk disappointing both of us.
^But not knowing if we will work out – I’ll regret it for the rest of my life.
ravi_2_4_nocall: ^Should I call her? Sigh. So many questions in my head.
^That was a bold, smooth move she made. Maybe because she was just bored. Or because I was just an easy target to practice her flirting game.
^Or because flirting with the barista is fun when you’ve yet to work out why he’s even a barista.
^Ah, my dear boss lady. Looks like I’m gonna have more shifts.
^Marie: No new shifts yet but got you sth better. Val dmed me for your no. And I gave it to her;)
^Wow. Wowww. She’s a Valkyrie alright. She takes what she wants.
^But... Our friendship is too much to lose. Better to keep what we have now than risk us not working out.
^Even if Val still accepts me after knowing about my family and our situation, her parents won’t. I’m broke, I’m neighbourhood-schooled, and – oh! Cherry on the cake – I’m Indian.
^I should know how it is with the Chinese majority. I can't even rent a flat from them - how would they feel if I were to date their daughter?
^And ...I like Val too much to rock her boat. What’s that French phrase she taught me?
^I think it’s best not to pick up this call.
chapter_2_ending_1: ^There’s that term Val taught me. Carpe diem - seize the day.
^If there’s a time for it, it’s now. Right. Here it goes, no regrets...
chapter_2_ending_2: ^C’est la vie. That’s life. It’s painful, it’s unfair.
